title: LIKE • DISLIKE • ALIKE • UNLIKE • LIKEN • LIKELY • UNLIKELY • LIKELIHOOD
subtitle: Structures + Examples + Explanations

sections.heading: LIKE (verb: enjoy / preference)
examples: I like ice cream.
Jane will like them.
Michelle likes to go to the gym.
My husband and I like ordering pizza.
sections.explanation: Use 'like' to show enjoyment or a preference. Infinitive and gerund are both possible. Sometimes gerund = enjoyment, infinitive = habit, but in daily use both are common.

sections.heading: DON'T LIKE (negative)
examples: I don't like spiders.
She doesn't like to share her pens.
We don't like spending too much money on pizza.
sections.explanation: The natural, everyday negative form of 'like'.

sections.heading: DISLIKE (stronger, more formal)
structure: express a dislike for + noun (noun form)
examples: I dislike the way Adam speaks to people.
My parents dislike my new tattoo.
Emily expresses her dislike for anything not her idea.
sections.explanation: Stronger and more formal than 'don't like.' Not commonly used in casual speech.

sections.heading: LIKE (verb + like = similar)
structure: (sense verbs: look, sound, feel, taste, smell)
examples: This soap smells like roses.
You look like your mom.
It tastes like a dessert.
He dances like he's celebrating.
sections.explanation: Shows similarity. Add 'just' or 'exactly' for stronger similarity.

sections.heading: ALIKE (adjective / adverb)
examples: They look alike.
These songs sound alike.
Children and adults alike love hot chocolate.
Critics and readers alike loved the novel.
sections.explanation: Means 'similar' or 'equally.' Used after the verb, not before a noun.

sections.heading: GREAT MINDS THINK ALIKE (expression)
structure: Expression used when two people have the same idea
examples: You bought her a stationery set? So did I. Great minds think alike.

sections.heading: LIKEN (verb: compare)
examples: Getting a tattoo is likened to being stung by bees.
She likens her boss to a giant cockroach.
The internet age can be likened to the industrial revolution.
sections.explanation: Used to compare two things because they are similar. More formal.

sections.heading: UNLIKE (preposition: contrast)
structure: unlike someone + to + infinitive (out of character)
examples: Unlike you, I'm not good with computers.
Unlike many languages, English spelling is tricky.
My trip to Borneo was unlike anything I'd ever experienced.
It's unlike Christina to be late.
It's unlike me to have no motivation.
sections.explanation: Shows difference or contrast. Used with nouns, pronouns, and with 'someone + to' for unusual behavior.

sections.heading: LIKELY (adjective: probable)
examples: It's likely that she'll leave the job soon.
Schools are likely to stay closed.
You're likely to take the exam this year.
It's highly likely you won't get a response today.
sections.explanation: Used to predict something with strong probability.

sections.heading: UNLIKELY (adjective: not probable)
examples: It's unlikely that she'll find a job soon.
He's unlikely to change his mind.
It's highly unlikely you'll hear back today.

sections.heading: LIKELIHOOD (noun)
examples: What is the likelihood of you taking the IELTS exam?
Eating fatty foods increases the likelihood of a heart attack.
There is little likelihood that crime rates will fall.
There is every likelihood this branch will double in size.
In all likelihood, the program will close.
sections.explanation: Formal noun meaning probability or chance.
